awd_titl_txt: From Deterministic Dynamics to Thermodynamic Laws
awd_abstract_narration:
Statistical mechanics attempts to explain the thermodynamic behavior of large systems and to bridge the gap between the microscopic and macroscopic worlds.  Equilibrium statistical mechanics is relatively well-developed, but many problems in non-equilibrium (i.e., irreversible) statistical mechanics have not been well answered yet.  In particular, the derivation of macroscopic transport laws from microscopic deterministic dynamics is a century-old challenge (for example, Fourier's law of heat conduction from microscopic heat conduction).  In this project, the investigator studies the derivation of thermodynamic properties of a gas that is not at thermal equilibrium, starting from a microscopic particle description of the gas.  The microscopic heat conduction problem under study is representative of numerous physical systems that are intrinsically high-dimensional, multiscale, noisy, and non-equilibrium.  Mathematical advances on this problem will be of value for other areas of science where non-equilibrium dynamics is an important feature, including materials science, neuroscience, molecular dynamics, fluid dynamics, and bio-chemical networks.  The project includes research experience opportunities for undergraduate students.

In this project, the investigator studies how thermodynamic properties are derived from non-equilibrium microscopic heat conduction models.  The aim is to develop a series of results that connect microscopic deterministic particle systems, mesoscopic stochastic differential equations, and macroscopic thermodynamic laws.  Starting from a deterministic kinetic particle system that models the heat conduction among gas particles in a tube with different temperatures at two ends, the project looks numerically for a mathematically tractable stochastic energy exchange process that preserves the main dynamical features of the deterministic problem, examines its stochastic stability and the mesoscopic limit problem when the scale of local dynamics increases, and derives macroscopic thermodynamic properties related to thermal conductivity, long-range correlation, the local thermodynamic equilibrium, and the fluctuation theorem.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In terms of the intellectual merit, the PI has accomplished the following research results.

 

A.    Many real-world problems are intrinsically nonequilibrium (irreversible), noisy, and high dimensional. Heat conduction model belongs to this category. Supported by this grant, the PI derived a series of nonequilibrium thermodynamic properties from a billiards-like microscopic heat conduction model rigorously and computationally. B. The PI developed a series of data-driven computational methods regarding the asymptotical properties, such as stationary distribution and speed of convergence to the stationary distribution, of low and high dimensional random-perturbed systems. Applications to sensitivity analysis and machine learning are also studied. These methods are not only used in the PI’s study of nonequilibrium dynamics, but also standing alone contributions to the mathematical computation community. C. The PI also studies the nonequilibrium properties of neuronal field models, with focus on the mechanism of Gamma-oscillation. D. Motivated by his result from billiards-like heat conduction models, the PI has started to study a nonlinear chain model that is derived from the wave turbulence theory. This study will be continued by the support his current grant.

 

In terms of broader impact, this grant has supported four REU students to participate in summer research programs supervised by the PI. Two of those four REU students are from underrepresented groups. This grant also supports the PI to participant in several research conferences to disseminate his results. The presentation given by the PI helps students and young researchers to learn new techniques and recent progress in nonequilibrium statistical mechanics. In addition, every summer the PI teaches a data science summer camp for high school students, many of those are from underrepresented groups. All these activities benefit the development and diversity of the STEM community.
